Award.AwardTitle: Fiber-based Hydrogels using Flow-induced Gelation Strategies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hydrogels, which are water-filled polymer networks, are important soft materials with beneficial properties that are currently in demand for tissue engineering, wound healing and various drug delivery applications. There are numerous methods for producing hydrogels, however many of these methods are strongly dependent on chemical composition and or chemical reactions. This award supports the development of a novel family of hydrogel materials produced from long and flexible fibers using a mechanical approach that does not rely on chemical reactions. This phenomenon, where flowing a suspension of microfibers causes the fibers to knot and entangle into a continuous network, is a largely unexplored field but has the potential to contribute significantly to the scientific, engineering, healthcare and industrial communities as it offers a simple and novel alternative route to engineering porous hydrogels with well-controlled properties. This study requires a multidisciplinary effort drawing upon concepts from materials science, flow processing, fluid mechanics, chemistry and bioengineering. The multidisciplinary nature of the research program will provide a rich learning experience for graduate and undergraduate students.

The primary research objectives of this project are focused on building a fundamental understanding of the mechanism of gelation of microfibers and the resultant properties of the fiber-based hydrogels when subjected to various flow conditions, thus establishing the structure-property relationships of flow-produced fiber-based hydrogels. These relationships will guide the design and processing parameters for producing fiber-based hydrogels for target applications, such as tissue engineering and surgical adhesives. This research involves both experimental and computational approaches to optimize the design and production of fiber-based hydrogels from flow processing. The experimental component of this project involves microfluidic approaches for fiber synthesis, rheological characterization of fiber suspensions and hydrogels, and imaging analysis of hydrogel microstructure. The computational component focuses on numerical simulation methods to model fiber knotting and entanglements when the suspended fibers are subjected to diverse stress conditions. In addition, the research can contribute meaningful insights to the existing body of literature on the flow properties of suspensions of long and slender objects, which is a very important theme in many industrial processes. Another significant outcome is the development of a unique paradigm for injectable hydrogels that utilizes micron-sized building blocks in a process that is entirely mechanical as the suspension gels in situ during injection without chemical reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hydrogels are versatile soft materials with valuable properties, including high water content and tunable mechanical properties. They are used in various personal care and food products, in contact lenses, drug delivery, water remediation, and bioengineering. In addition, injectable hydrogels are desirable for applications such as 3D bioprinting and regenerative medicine, as they can flow to a desired location and gel rapidly. The range of cross-linking mechanisms to produce hydrogels is broad, varying from chemical approaches such as free-radical polymerization to physical mechanisms exhibited by some block copolymer or polymer-nanoparticle systems. There are also some systems where the action of flowing the solution or suspension triggers gelation, for example, vigorous shaking causes the reversible gelation of polymer-clay suspensions. This project explored a novel method to produce hydrogels by the flow processing of flexible fiber suspensions, where gelation is a mechanical process that does not depend on chemical reactions or interactions, but involves the formation of topological entanglements among fibers.1  

The intellectual merit of this project encompasses systematic experimental and theoretical studies on (1) the process of producing microfibers, (2) the dynamics of individual fibers in flow, and (3) studies of concentrated suspensions of fibers that form hydrogels when sheared or subjected to extensional flows. In our study, the building blocks for the macroscopic hydrogel are flexible, hydrophilic microfibers, typically of high aspect ratio (length much larger than the fiber radius). We studied the kinetics of the microfluidic flow process used to produce the microfibers to better tailor the fiber properties.2 We also explored other techniques to controllably produce micron-sized liquid jets, such as selective withdrawal, which have the potential to be useful for high throughput fiber production.3 To characterize the mechanical properties of the microscopic hydrogel objects, we developed different approaches; one such approach was a collaborative effort to measure the elastic modulus of hydrogel microspheres based on their deformations in extensional flows.4

In this project, it was important to take steps to understand the dynamics of a single fiber in flow. In a collaborative effort, we used simulations to study the behavior of a single flexible fiber in shear flow and were able to document, and quantify in some cases with analytical models, the tumbling dynamics and buckling of the fibers in the flow.5,6 The results are now motivating additional experiments that we are performing to further advance our understanding of the relation of fiber shape to flow, which is a microstructural property that is important to suspensions of fibers.

Experimentally, we studied the rheological behavior of the microfiber suspensions, as well as the hydrogels produced from extruding the suspensions. We determined that the shear thickening in suspensions of highly flexible microfiber suspensions (where the viscosity of the suspension increases with increasing shear rate) can, in part, can be attributed to the flexibility of the fibers which leads to bending and topological entanglements.1 These results expand our knowledge of the rheological behavior of fiber suspensions. Furthermore, the observation of gelation above some critical volume fraction of fibers, depending on the fiber aspect ratio and the flow conditions, indicates a viable mechanism for forming hydrogels without chemical reactions or chemical interactions. Soft fiber-based hydrogels formed via this mechanical approach may be broadly useful, and we have been motivated to develop further projects to explore their efficacy as wound healing materials. To expand the range of achievable mechanical properties, we have also begun to investigate combining the mechanical interlocking mechanism with electrostatic interactions. In a preliminary study, we observed that a flexible fiber wraps as it adheres to an oppositely charged curved particle depending on the properties of the fiber and the surrounding solution, suggesting a new potential approach for generating gel-like networks from microscopic building blocks.7  

The broader impacts of this project focused on the educational themes underlying the development of fiber-based hydrogels. Multiple postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students were trained in theoretical concepts and experimental techniques in microfluidics, rheology, materials science, fluid mechanics and polymer chemistry. To date, the project has produced 7 peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in development. In addition, this project has been successful at growing new collaborations, including international collaborations. We have been committed to disseminating knowledge about these research themes in various public outreach events, e.g., giving demonstrations and interactive lectures specifically targeting K-12 students.

References:

1. Perazzo, A. et al. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 2017, 114, E8557.

2. Pan, Z., et al. Phys. Rev. Lett. 2020, 125, 264502.

3. Slutzky, M. et al. Soft Matter 2019, 15, 9553.

4. Villone, M. M. et al. Soft Matter 2019, 15, 880.

5. Słowicka, A. M., et al. Phys. Rev. E, 2020, 101, 023104.

6. Zuk, P. J., et al. J. Fluid Mech. 2021, 914, A31.

7. Nunes, J. K., et al. Soft Matter 2021, 17, 3609.  

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2021
Modified by: Janine K Nunes

They are used in various personal care and food products, in contact lenses, drug delivery, water remediation, and bioengineering.
